Steps:

``` sh
$ git clone https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell.git
$ git submodule update --init --recursive -- src/monad src/windows-build

Add "C:\Users\scxsvc\AppData\Local\Microsoft\dotnet\cli\bin\" to Environment Variable "PATH"
Run PowerShell with administrator:
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri https://raw.githubusercontent.com/dotnet/cli/rel/1.0.0/scripts/obtain/install.ps1 -OutFile install.ps1
./install.ps1 -version 1.0.0.001425 -channel beta

cd PowerShell
```

body:
It shows many $<5>when I used "SSH Secure Shell Client" to connect to Linux box and do things(Get-Host) below:
![powershelllinuxissue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16585827/13341788/a8d254dc-dc76-11e5-8afb-2d90f3d64772.png)
Steps:

``` sh
$ git clone --recursive https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell.git

$ sh -c 'echo "deb [arch=amd64] http://apt-mo.trafficmanager.net/repos/dotnet/ trusty main" > /etc/apt/sources.list.d/dotnetdev.list'
$ apt-key adv --keyserver apt-mo.trafficmanager.net --recv-keys 417A0893
$ apt-get update
$ apt-get install dotnet=1.0.0.001425-1

$ apt-get install g++ cmake make lldb-3.6 strace

$ apt-get install libpam0g-dev libssl-dev libcurl4-openssl-dev libboost-filesystem-dev

$ cd PowerShell
$ dotnet restore
$ ./build.sh
$ ./bin/powershell.sh
```

body:
Running `chsh -s /bin/bash`, requires a password, which it wouldn't let me enter.  Seems related to bug #484 .  could be a bug in the linux program chsh though.  Thoughts?

Repro:
1. in a running powershell session, execute `chsh -s /bin/bash` asks for a password. 

Expected:
enter password, no output, default shell is now bash.

Actual:
When typing password, it enters a newline upon typing first character, then errors, stating that the program "password" could not be found.

Workaround:
I edited the /etc/passwd file directly under sudo.  it may be possible to switch to bash using the `echo tty` workaround in #484 as well, but I think this definitely needs to be addressed as users will eventually be expected to adopt powershell as the default native host, as well as be able to move back and forth from different native shells easily.

body:
Add cross-platform `Start-PSBuild` and `Start-PSPackage` commands to the `PowerShellGitHubDev` module. The former replaces `build.ps1` (which can soon be deleted) and `build.sh` (which cannot be deleted until we have a package available for Travis). The latter will build a `deb` package on Ubuntu 14.04, and a `pkg` on OS X (Windows MSI is not supported; will need help with that).

During development, a `package.sh` was written for each platform, and I have retained this history on purpose so that those who can't yet self-host can build a package. Packaging uses the awesome tool [fpm](https://github.com/jordansissel/fpm) to get up and running quickly. I believe it satisfies our current requirements.

Pending merge and a separate review for documentation updates, I'd like to release version 0.1.0 with packages for both supported platforms.

Note that this PR includes #568, because self-hosting necessitates at least a somewhat improved user experience.

The module still works on FullCLR, and AppVeyor has been updated to use it explicitly. @vors I believe we could merge `build.FullCLR.ps1` in as well.

Functions that should later be added to the module include replacements for `pester.sh`, `xunit.sh`, `omibuild.sh`, and `psrp.sh`. We should not remove these scripts until all developers are comfortable self-hosting PowerShell for building.
title: Enable self-hosting

title: Running native interactive command-line app breaks history

body:
Windows PowerShell allows both `\` and `/` be path delimiters.

Consider

```
#  Full PS on Windows
PS C:\> 'foo' > bar
PS C:\> cat ./bar
foo
PS C:\> cat .\bar
foo

```

Versus 

```
# Linux version
PSL /Users/vors/dev/PowerShell-Linux> 'foo' > bar
PSL /Users/vors/dev/PowerShell-Linux> cat ./bar
foo
PSL /Users/vors/dev/PowerShell-Linux> cat .\bar
cat : Cannot find path '/Users/vors/dev/PowerShell-Linux/.\bar' because it does not exist.
```

It's a problem for **porting**: there are scripts that could run as-is, but don't because of the wrong path delimiters.

On the other hand, on Linux you can create a folder `foo\bar`, so adding `\` as alternative path separator would make this corner case harder.

This problem can be solved with additional escaping 

```
cd foo`\bar
```

**Sidenote**: 'Set-Location' (`cd`) currently fails for it, but `Get-ChildItem` (`ls`) works

```
PSL /Users/vors/dev/PowerShell-Linux> ls ./foo\bar/


    Directory: /Users/vors/dev/PowerShell-Linux/foo\bar


Mode                LastWriteTime         Length Name                                                                                                                    
----                -------------         ------ ----                                                                                                                    
------          2/20/16   9:38 PM              6 1   


PSL /Users/vors/dev/PowerShell-Linux> cd ./foo\bar/
cd : An object at the specified path /Users/vors/dev/PowerShell-Linux/foo\bar does not exist.
```

labels.name: Issue-Bug

body:
We have 24 conflicting names between PS aliases and `/bin`, `/usr/bin`, etc folders 

```
# /bin
cat              
cp               
echo             
kill             
ls               
mv               
ps               
pwd              
rm               
rmdir            
sleep
# /usr/bin
cd                     
clear                  
cpp                    
diff                   
fc                     
man                    
ri                     
sort                   
tee                    
type                   
write         
# /usr/sbin
ac
# /sbin
mount
```

We need to figure out what's out story about it.

I think it make sense to play around with different options to see pros and cons on practice.
#### ~~Try it~~ (the snippet is outdated, see the new snippet for 0.3.0 bellow)

You can add this snippet to your profile and easily switch from one mode to another
- **Remove-PSAliases** will remove aliases, so you can use native utilities.
- **Set-PSAliases** will restore aliases.

``` powershell
$global:__aliases = @(
    'cat',              
    'cp',               
    'echo',             
    'kill',             
    'ls',               
    'mv',               
    'ps',               
    'pwd',              
    'rm',               
    'rmdir',            
    'sleep',
    'cd',                     
    'clear',                  
    'cpp',                    
    'diff',                   
    'fc',                     
    'man',                    
    'ri',                     
    'sort',                   
    'tee',                    
    'type',                   
    'write',         
    'ac',
    'mount'
) 

function Set-PSAliases
{
    $global:__aliases | % { 
        Write-Host "Adding $_"
        Set-Alias $_ $global:__aliases_backup[$_] -Scope Global 
    }      
}

function Remove-PSAliases
{
    if (-not $global:__aliases_backup) {
        $global:__aliases_backup = @{}
        $global:__aliases | % {
            $global:__aliases_backup[$_] = (Get-Command $_).ResolvedCommandName
        }
    }

    $global:__aliases | % { 
        Write-Host "Removing $_"
        while (Test-Path alias:$_) {
            Remove-Item -Force alias:$_ 
        }
    }
}
```

body:
With the latest packages, a lot more System.Console API is available. This commit implements what is now available through the API.

Where an API functions correctly on Linux, the result of a call through PowerShell works as expected. Where it is not, a nice `PlatformNotSupported` exception is thrown (and displayed by PowerShell).

On Linux:
- `$host.ui.RawUI.WindowTitle` can be set but cannot be get
- `$host.ui.RawUI.CusorPosition` can be set and get
- `$host.ui.RawUI.CursorSize` can be get but cannot be set
- `$host.ui.RawUI.MaxPhysicalWindowSize` can be get
- `$host.ui.RawUI.MaxWindowSize` can be get
- `$host.ui.RawUI.WindowPosition` can be get but cannot be set
- `$host.ui.RawUI.WindowSize` can be get but cannot be set
- `$host.ui.RawUI.ReadKey` can be be used, but is only approximate

body:
## Motivation

I'm trying to do an equivalent of bash `alias grep='grep --color=auto'`
Since, Set-Alias [doesn't support parameters](https://github.com/vors/ParamAlias), I'm doing it with a function
## Repro

``` powershell
function grep
{
    grep --color=auto $args
}
'123' | grep 1
```
### Expected

123 with red 1
### Actual

```
Unhandled Exception: System.Management.Automation.ScriptCallDepthException: The script failed due to call depth overflow.
   at System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.PipelineBase.Invoke(IEnumerable input)
   at System.Management.Automation.Runspaces.Pipeline.Invoke()
   at System.Management.Automation.PowerShell.Worker.ConstructPipelineAndDoWork(Runspace rs, Boolean performSyncInvoke)
   at System.Management.Automation.PowerShell.Worker.CreateRunspaceIfNeededAndDoWork(Runspace rsToUse, Boolean isSync)
   at System.Management.Automation.PowerShell.CoreInvokeHelper[TInput,TOutput](PSDataCollection`1 input, PSDataCollection`1 output, PSInvocationSettings settings)
   at System.Management.Automation.PowerShell.CoreInvoke[TInput,TOutput](PSDataCollection`1 input, PSDataCollection`1 output, PSInvocationSettings settings)
   at System.Management.Automation.PowerShell.CoreInvoke[TOutput](IEnumerable input, PSDataCollection`1 output, PSInvocationSettings settings)
   at System.Management.Automation.PowerShell.Invoke(IEnumerable input, PSInvocationSettings settings)
   at Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host.Listener.ExecuteHelper(String cmd, Object input)
   at Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host.Listener.Execute(String cmd)
   at Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host.Listener.Run()
   at Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host.Program.Main(String[] args)
```

labels.description: Issue has been identified as a bug in the product
labels.name: Issue-Bug

title: Unhandled ScriptCallDepthException

body:
Consider

```
ping -c 4 ya.ru | grep 64
```

Run it in PS and in bash. Compare UX.
In PS output of ping is collected,  then it's passed down the pipe all together.
In bash you see output of grep instantly after ping send one line to the pipe.

As @BrucePay pointed out it never appeared to be a problem on windows due to the lack of pipeable native command-line tools.

As a minimum, we should sort out this buffering flow.
Desirable: improve pipe speed for certain cases (i.e. native command to native command).

Open question: can we use a native pipe to provide a compatible speed, when pipeline doesn't involve PS commands?

body:
`$ss = [securestring]::New()`
`$ss.AppendChar("f")`
`$c = [pscredential]::New("Redmond\user",$ss)`
`new-pssession -computername nosuchcomputer -credential $c`
`new-possession : Unable to load DLL 'api-ms-win-core-registry-l1-1-0.dll': the specified module could not be found.`
`(Exception from HRESULT: 0x8007007E)`

we probably shouldn't be checking the registry

note: I don't believe we even get to attempting to open the connection, so it doesn't matter that the credential/computername is bogus

body:
This PR includes fixes for:
1.  Tab completion of file names so that they are preceded by "./" or ".\"
2.  Directories have trailing slash
3.  Handle files with spaces in them.
4.  Files with "..\" are displayed correctly.
5.  Up/down arrow key requiring double-tap to show correctly
6.  Hitting "down-arrow" and then "up-arrow" did not display history correctly
7.  General cleaning of code to use boundary-checking instead of try-catch blocks.
title: Combo PR that fixes tab-completion and up/down arrows

body:
This is part of https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/543 , but I could not create a simple repro, hence a separate issue.

The origin of this test is `tests\Engine\ExtensibleTypeSystem\COM.Tests.ps`
## Repro
-  `cp \\scratch2\scratch\sevoroby\MshComTest\MshComTest.dll c:\temp`
-  You need to run this from elevated prompt: `regsvr32.exe C:\Temp\MshComTest.dll`   <- make sure COM registration succeed.
-  `New-Object -ComObject "MshComTest.ObjectParameter"`
## Expected

```

VariantProperty
---------------



```
## Actual

```
New-Object : Retrieving the COM class factory for component with CLSID
{795A1D7E-950A-4740-BD3D-5447A4A36606} failed due to the following error:
80040154 Class not registered (Exception from HRESULT: 0x80040154
(REGDB_E_CLASSNOTREG)).
At line:1 char:1
+ New-Object -ComObject "MshComTest.ObjectParameter"
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : ResourceUnavailable: (:) [New-Object], COMExcept
   ion
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : NoCOMClassIdentified,Microsoft.PowerShell.Comman
   ds.NewObjectCommand
```

title: New-Object -Com doesn't work for custom Com objects

body:
When using either Tmux or Screen terminal multiplexers, `Console.CursorTop` becomes incorrect. Since we use this as our [anchor](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/1ec5676f25d9c6e65b7fae481bd518cb7ed660ef/src/Microsoft.PowerShell.Linux.Host/readline.cs#L681) in readline, it causes our input and output to always come from the top-left corner, instead of following the prompt like one would expect with a shell.

This behavior does not appear when `TERM=xterm`, because `Console.CursorTop` is then correct.

.NET bug tracked in dotnet/corefx#6091.

Diff I used to confirm:

``` c#
             public Cursor()
             {
+                Console.WriteLine($"input {Console.IsInputRedirected}");
+                Console.WriteLine($"output {Console.IsOutputRedirected}");
+                Console.WriteLine($"top {Console.CursorTop}");
+                Console.WriteLine($"left {Console.CursorLeft}");
                 this.anchorTop = Console.CursorTop;
                 this.anchorLeft = Console.CursorLeft;
             }
```

``` sh
$ export TERM=xterm
$ ./bin/powershell --noprofile
PS /home/andrew/src/PowerShell-Linux>
input False
output False
top 51
left 0

$ export TERM=ansi
$ ./bin/powershell --noprofile
PS /home/andrew/src/PowerShell-Linux>
input False
output False
top 51
left 0

$ export TERM=screen
$ ./bin/powershell --noprofile
PS /home/andrew/src/PowerShell-Linux>
input False
output False
top 0
left 0
```

Note how with `TERM=screen`, top is 0. This breaks us.

labels.description: Issue has been identified as a bug in the product
labels.name: Issue-Bug

body:
## BVT/DRT

I made a run of our BVT/DRT tests with FullCLR bits built from GitHub sources.
BVT/DRT are our P0 tests.

Results

```
BVT: total=500 Pass=496 Fail=4 Error=0 Skip=0 Unspecified=0 Blocked=0 
DRT: total=3248 Pass=3165 Fail=57 Error=8 Skip=4 Unspecified=14 Blocked=0 
P0: total=5891 Pass=5715 Fail=90 Error=0 Skip=72 Unspecified=0 Blocked=14 

Start time 2/12/2016 1:48:03 PM
End time 2/12/2016 2:44:31 PM
Elapsed, 00:56:28.5847284
```

We take a look to a couple of failures with @JamesWTruher and we observe legitimate problems so far.
## Action plan
-  **Goal**: get a parity in the test results with official windows build
-  We should continue to analyse the rest of results and will provide a simple repro (in form of pester test) where possible. (see example below)
-  We need to incorporate this regression suite in CI process and fix issues.
-  At the same time, we should start to aligning our tests suites (FullPS, LinuxPS, CorePS). This regression test suite is a good starting point for it.
-  Tests should contain info about their origin: a pointer to the original file in a comment.
## Example

``` powershell
Describe "BVT/DRT Regression Suite" {
    # original test
    # \monad\tests\mae\PowerShell\tests\Provider\Providers\Lite.Providers.FileSystemProvider.AlternateDataStreams.ps1
    It 'can use alternate AlternateDataStreams with : syntax' {
        $file = [IO.Path]::GetTempFilename()
        Set-Content $file -Stream Stream1 "World"
        cat "${file}:Stream1" | Should Be "World"
    }
}
```

body:
The command `dotnet run` builds and runs in one shot (given the `Linux.Host` project), negating the need to build with scripts (at this point wrappers around `dotnet publish`).

However, the last piece of the puzzle is to have `libpsl-native.so` deployed as project content automatically, and this is blocked on dotnet/cli#710. We've worked around by building and copying in `build.sh`, but it will be nice to deprecate this.

body:
These do not really belong in the `Linux.Host` project. The `ps1xml` files and some modules belong to `System.Management.Automation`, and some other modules belong to their respective module projects.

The current state of affairs is unfortunate for the FullCLR PowerShell builds, as its top project is _not_ `Linux.Host`, which has the required content. Some of the content dependencies are shared, but we cannot move them to their correct homes until dotnet/cli#753 is resolved.

This massively reduces the complexity of our build scripts, by using the `content` field of the Linux.Host's `project.json` file to deploy the files when publishing automatically.

This required adding the files to the tree, but as my commits note, this should not be an issue.

The Pester submodule was also moved, so after updating to this commit, `git submodule update` must be done (and likely `rm -rf test/Pester`).

body:
As an easier way to demonstrate PowerShell (on Linux) for those who don't want to build it, we'll make a Debian package we can just share internally. Then the requirements to try the demo will simply be: create an Ubuntu 14.04 VM (a few clicks in Azure), download the `powershell.deb` package; `sudo dpkg -i powershell.deb`, and run `powershell`.

This will also be nice to start self-hosting.

I am going to utilize the .NET CLI team's [Debian Package Tool](https://github.com/dotnet/cli/tree/rel/1.0.0/packaging/debian/package_tool).

title: Fix tab completion results for directories

body:
Hey @vors:

I guess they updated how dependencies are supposed to be specified. The oddity we see where the lock files complain about needing to be restored even after a restore (like [here](https://travis-ci.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/builds/20780608#L2426)) _may_ be due to our use of `frameworkAssemblies`, as discuessed in dotnet/cli#1171.

I think all we need to do is remove any version specified under framework assemblies. I'll give it a whack.
